awd_titl_txt: Numerical Studies of Negative Bouyancy-Induced Thermohaline Circulation on Arctic Continental Shelves
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal is part of a systematic study of the Arctic                       environment and its role in global change which is promoted                     by NSF's Arctic System Science Program.  It is a three year                     project to understand the dynamics of the thermohaline                          circulation associated with surface salinity fluxes by                          applying a numerical model in a sequence of process-oriented                    studies.  Surface cooling and brine rejection during ice                        formation lead to large surface salinity fluxes in many                         areas of the Arctic Ocean, particularly over the continental                    shelves.  This negative buoyancy input increases the water                      density to such an extent that it may sink to the bottom and                    induce thermohaline circulation patterns with may generate                      dense-water bottom currents in the form of plumes.  Such                        dense-water plumes may transport shelf water across the                         shelf and deposit it into the deep Arctic basins, thus                          contributing to the large-scale Arctic circulation.
